content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata>   <idinfo>     <citation>       <citeinfo>         <origin>U.S. Geological Survey, Central Energy Resources Team</origin>         <pubdate>2002</pubdate>         <title>Map Service Showing Geology, Oil and Gas Fields, and Geologic Provinces of Africa</title>         <geoform>Live GIS Data and Maps</geoform>         <pubinfo>           <publish>U.S. Geological Survey, Central Energy Resources Team</publish>         </pubinfo>    <onlink>http://certmapper.cr.usgs.gov/arcgis/rest/services/geology/africa/MapServer</onlink>         <onlink>http://certmapper.cr.usgs.gov/pubs/servlet/MapViewerBroker?Service=WorldAfrica&OVMap=WorldAfrica_overview&project=world</onlink>    <onlink>http://certmapper.cr.usgs.gov/arcgis/services/geology/africa/MapServer/WMSServer?request=GetCapabilities&service=WMS</onlink>         <lworkcit>           <citeinfo>             <origin>Feliks M. Persits, Thomas S. Ahlbrandt, Michelle L. Tuttle, Ronald R. Charpentier, Michael E. Brownfield</origin>             <pubdate>200206</pubdate>             <title>Map showing Geology, Oil and Gas Fields, and Geologic Provinces of Africa</title>             <edition>version 2.0</edition>             <geoform>Digital Maps</geoform>             <serinfo>               <sername>U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report</sername>               <issue>OFR-97-470-A</issue>             </serinfo>             <pubinfo>               <pubplace>Denver, Colorado</pubplace>               <publish>U.S. Geological Survey, Central Energy Resources Team</publish>             </pubinfo>             <onlink>http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1997/ofr-97-470/OF97-470A/</onlink>           </citeinfo>         </lworkcit>       </citeinfo>     </citation>     <descript>       <abstract>This map service includes geology, oil and gas field centerpoints, and geologic provinces of Africa with some of these components extended into geographically adjacent areas. This digital compilation is an interim product of the U.S. Geological Survey's World Energy Project (WEP) and part of a series on CD-ROM. The goal of the WEP is to assess the undiscovered, technically recoverable oil and gas resources of the world.  Results of this assessment were reported in the year 2000 (see USGS DDS-60). </abstract>       <purpose>The data provide government, the geologic community, consultants, and the general public with the geological basis for small scale natural resource surveys, exploration, and analysis.     The version 1.0 of this CD-ROM was published in 1997 (see Persits and others, 1997). There are several reasons to issue this version 2.0, as follows:  1. ESRI's ArcView shapefiles were in Robinson projection.  It was found that Robinson projection in ArcView is an implementation that differs from one used in workstation ArcInfo and therefore shows different values.  This version 2.0 uses all the spatial data in Geographic coordinates projected into Mercator projection for the map.  2. Certain off-shore provinces have been expanded to include the 4000 meters water depth.  3. Geologic characteristics and estimated values for undiscovered oil and gas resources have been added to the geologic province coverage.</purpose>     </descript>     <timeperd>       <timeinfo> (ESRI), and are used with permission. Shapefiles covering oil and gas field centerpoints contain intellectual property of Petroconsultants International Data Corporation, and are used with permission. End users are permitted to use these data sets for their own internal use, including derivative work, but are prohibited from redistributing these data individually or in a derivative work to third parties. </useconst>     <ptcontac>       <cntinfo>         <cntperp>           <cntper>Dr. Thomas Ahlbrandt</cntper>           <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey</cntorg>         </cntperp>         <cntpos>Project Chief</cntpos>         <cntaddr>           <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype>           <address>Denver Federal Center, MS 939 P.O.Box 25046</address>           <city>Denver</city>           <state>CO</state>           <postal>80225</postal>           <country>USA</country>         </cntaddr>         <cntvoice>303-236-5776</cntvoice>         <cntemail>datamgt@usgs.gov</cntemail>       </cntinfo>     </ptcontac>     <browse>       <browsen>http://certmapper.cr.usgs.gov/data/we/graphic/ms_africa_gel_prov.jpg</browsen>       <browset>JPEG</browset>     </browse>     <datacred> Digital Geologic Map Compilation in Arc/Info - Feliks Persits Geologic Attribution - Feliks Persits, Thomas Ahlbrandt, Michelle Tuttle, Ronald Charpentier, Michael Brownfield. Implementation of Metadata- Feliks Persits Arcview and ArcExplorer projects - Feliks Persits Map design and verification - Feliks Persits Adobe Acrobat design - Kenneth Takahashi CD-ROM implementation - Feliks Persits </datacred>     <native> Windows NT Version 4.0 (Build 1381) Service Pack 6; ESRI ArcInfo 8.1.0.415; ESRI ArcGIS Desktop 8.1; ESRI ArcView 3.2; ESRI ArcExplorer 2.0 </native>   </idinfo>   <dataqual>     <attracc>       <attraccr>The overall accuracy is based on the accuracy of the general geology coverage. Because all the attributes are of character type, only correctness of polygon labeling can be provided (see below). 1. Attribute item "GLG" is abstracted from fill colors and patterns of source map denoting geologic age of surficial outcrops.  Units colored as land surface water bodies are attributed as "H2O". Sea and ocean are attributed as "Sea". Areas outside of African continent are labeled as "oth". 2. Standard verification of attribute reliability is performed with the Arc/Info command LABELERRORS to find polygons without an assigned character value or with more than one value. A comparison between the color plot and the original paper map is carried out by on-screen visual examination. The coverages are superimposed on a registered and rectified gray-scale scanned image of the original map and inspected. All errors detected in attributes are corrected. The scanned images of each of the five sheets of the original paper map (from UNESCO base geologic map) were transformed to Transverse Mercator projection with RMS error not more than 2500 m (0.5 mm in original paper map). No rubber transformation applied. Gray-scale images were used as background images in ARCEDIT digitizing. Maximum shift of a line in a coverage from centerline of its copy on image did not exceed 1500-1700 m.  The final plot of 1:5,000,000 scale was superimposed on top of an original map, maximum error did not exceed 3500 m.</attraccr>       <qattracc>         <attraccv>good</attraccv>         <attracce>This is a deductive estimate based on a polygon overlay of a coverage plot and the original materials.  Checks by both the compiler and an independent reviewer identified labeling and classification errors which were corrected.  Any remaining errors are most likely a result of misinterpretation of source data.</attracce>       </qattracc>     </attracc>     <logic>The data set originated from a collection of ARC/INFO coverages that were topologically consistent.  The fuzzy tolerance has been consistent through each processing step (500 m or 0.005 degree).  Based on this fuzzy tolerance value, all undershoots and overshoots were detected and deleted.  Execution of Arc/Info CLEAN command indicated the original coverage is topologically clean.  Duplicate lines, overshoots and undershoots, if any, were corrected.  All polygons are closed and labeled.  Polygons at the edge of the map are closed with a map outer polygon.</logic>     <complete>Several geologic age subdivisions on the original (UNESCO) 1:5,000,000 geologic map were combined into single units.  As of May, 2000 generalizations of the original geologic map (UNESCO) were carried out:   1.  All the Cretaceous units were combined into one.   2.  All the Precambrian subdivisions were combined into one.</complete>     <posacc>       <horizpa>         <horizpar>Because the original geologic maps are of 500 m. accuracy (0.1 mm on paper map of 1:5,000,000 scale), and scanned images were of 200 dot/inch resolution (0.12 mm on paper), the fuzzy tolerance for CLEAN program in ARC/INFO was set to 500 m.  Average positional accuracy can be evaluated as 1000 m or twice of the fuzzy tolerance.</horizpar>         <qhorizpa>           <horizpav>1.0 km</horizpav>           <horizpae>Overall relative position error was estimated by comparing a randomly selected set of locations on the ESRI World country coverage to the shoreline and state boundaries on the final geology coverage.  RMS error is 1.0 km (0.2 mm of the original paper map).</horizpae>         </qhorizpa>       </horizpa>     </posacc>     <lineage>       <srcinfo>         <srccite>           <citeinfo>
